content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit the public by reducing traffic congestion, transportation emissions, energy usage, and improving railroad operations. Eligible projects will be determined by the Secretary of Transportation. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" include increasing track capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving rail-road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and repairing track structures. Funding is not provided for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or construction of maintenance facilities. SEC. 103. INCLUSION IN STATE PLANS. Projects must be included in a long-range transportation plan, a State plan, or a transportation improvement program to be funded under this title. SEC. 104. COST SHARING. States must provide at least 20% of project costs funded under this title. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. Additional discretionary amounts are at the Secretary's discretion. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. The Secretary also uses 20% of the funds for grants for eligible projects of national significance with emphasis on projects with the greatest public benefit. Labor standards under this title require contractors to pay prevailing wages. Additionally, at least 10% of funds must be spent on small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Definitions are provided in section 1101(b)(2) of the Transportation Equity Act. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. The term "rail miles" refers to route miles, not track miles, and "railroad" includes freight, intercity passenger, and commuter rail transportation. TITLE II--FUNDING. SEC. 201. EXCISE TAX ON SALE OF CERTAIN TRAIN EQUIPMENT. Imposition of tax on railroad locomotives and rolling stock. The tax imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment is 5 percent of the selling price. Specified railroad equipment includes locomotives and other rolling stock. Regulations allow for the separate purchase and installation of parts and accessories within 6 months of the equipment being placed in service. A 5 percent tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment within 6 months of the equipment being placed in service. The tax does not apply to replacement parts or accessories, and owners of the business installing the parts are also liable for the tax. SEC. 202. TAX ON RAIL TRANSPORTATION OF PERSONS OR PROPERTY. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on October 1, 2003. Chapter 33 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting a new subchapter for transportation by rail, including taxes on transportation of persons and property. SEC. 4241 imposes a tax on taxable rail transportation of persons, with rates of 5% for commuter rail and 10% for other cases. The tax is paid by the person making the payment. SEC. 4242 deals with the transportation of property. A 1% tax is imposed on the amount paid for taxable rail transportation of property within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except for payments made outside the United States, where the tax is paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States. When a payment subject to tax is made outside the United States and the payer does not pay the tax, the tax must be paid by the recipient of the property in the United States and collected by the transporter of the taxable transportation. SEC. 4243. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel in the US excluding mass transit. "Transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders and tax deductions on refunds for untaxed purchases. The tax imposed by section 4241 requires deductions on refunds for untaxed purchases, with carriers responsible for paying any uncollected taxes. The tax imposed by section 4241 requires carriers to pay any uncollected taxes, as specified by the Secretary's regulations. SEC. 203. NATIONAL RAIL INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAM TRUST FUND. The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2003. Subchapter A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section establishing the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel used in trains, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by taxes on fuel used in trains and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund can only be used for expenditures related to the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
